awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Linking Pharmacokinetics to Epidemiological Models of Vector-Borne Diseases and Drug Resistance Prevention
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this research is to develop mathematical tools to improve understanding of how the behavior of drugs within the body, and their effects on pathogens, influence the spread of drug-resistant disease. Drugs that target microbes (antimicrobials) have saved millions of lives. But, because microbes evolve, over time antimicrobials reduce the population of pathogens that succumb to drugs and leave behind those that do not - a process called selection. Consequently, unbridled use of antimicrobials threatens their long-term efficacy - a concern since the discovery of penicillin in 1928. Today, drug resistance is recognized as a serious problem requiring urgent attention. Differential equations can describe mechanisms that drive changes in living systems; control theory can generate the best strategies to use these mechanisms to achieve a desired goal. These tools will help guide drug development and dosing protocols that balance the immediate benefits of administering antimicrobials with the long-term selection pressure imposed by these drugs. A mathematical framework that is adaptable to different disease systems could inform strategies to reduce the threat of resistant pathogens to global health and the attendant cost to society. Furthermore, this project will provide graduate students at Howard, Texas Tech, Lehigh, and the University of Kentucky, with the opportunity to intern at the Los Alamos National Laboratory, fostering connections outside of academia.  University of Kentucky students will also assist the lead investigator in mentoring high school students through a pilot Saturday Morning Math program that will provide hands-on experience with coding, modeling, and visualization of scientific results.

The investigators aim to construct a general mathematical framework, with vector-borne disease serving as a benchmark example, and build the tools needed to bridge the gap between within-host PK/PD (pharmacokinetics/pharmacodynamics) and population-level epidemiology, so that others may readily adapt the framework to their own studies of competing pathogens. The investigators will approach the problem of linking the fast dynamics of PK/PD to the comparatively slow population-level dynamics by introducing serial compartments in a system of nonlinear ordinary differential equations representing the progression of individuals through stages of treatment characterized by different drug concentrations and different durations. A stochastic sub-model is proposed to parameterize one of the functions that links within-host PK/PD to the population-level dynamics.  The proposed research is important because, to date, no general methods exist to analyze a staged-progression model where the stages have different durations. Such a model could provide results and insights that significantly improve the protocols for drug interventions in a way that mitigates the selection pressure leading to drug resistance. For example, it is unknown how the likely existence of backward bifurcation and the staged-progression approach with heterogeneous stages will interact and influence optimal treatment policy. Furthermore, the proposed parameter estimation, uncertainty, and identifiability analyses will likely lead to challenging mathematical and statistical problems requiring advances of existing methodologies.  

This project is funded by the Division of Mathematical Sciences Mathematical Biology Program and Division of Human Resource Development HBCU-UP.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The risk of antimicrobial drug resistance has been a known concern for decades. While drugs have saved millions of lives, increasing levels of pathogen resistance threaten the efficacy of pharmaceutical interventions as drug development struggles to keep up with these ever-changing pathogens. The spread of antibiotic resistance remains one of the world?s largest concerns and drug-resistant vector-borne parasites challenge existing public health interventions.  The major objective of this research was to better our understanding of how pharmacokinetics (PK), the drug dynamics within the body, and pharmacodynamics (PD), the effects of the drug on an organism, influence population-level transmission and the resulting spread of drug-resistant pathogens, and what can be done to help to mitigate these concerns.  We developed a suite of mathematical models that start to bridge the gap between within host PK/PD and between-host transmission of competing pathogens. These models are useful to help guide drug development and dosing protocols that balance the immediate benefits of antimicrobials with the long-term selection pressure imposed by using these drugs.

In particular, we developed two mathematical frameworks that expand current population level modeling methods and applied them to study the impact of drug therapies on the spread of drug resistant vector-borne diseases like malaria.  Firstly, we develop approaches that allow the time span for the duration of infection for individuals, with or without treatment, to be driven by data. Mathematically, we incorporated realistic distributions for the waiting times of the different epidemiological stages into our population level model of disease spread. This allows the model to describe the interaction between the level of drug concentration and pathogen loads inside an infected individual host more accurately. Secondly, we developed modeling frameworks that incorporate seasonal temperature variations into malaria models. Temperature affects many aspects of mosquito population dynamics, as well as traits of the malaria parasite within the mosquito. We incorporated data-driven seasonality into the models by integrating periodic spline functions into the model equations. This novel spline methodology allows us to incorporate temperature-dependent mosquito and pathogen traits and capture seasonal effects of diseases in different regions more realistically. We presented our findings to the scientific community at national and international conferences and published the results in scientific journals.

This award supported two graduate students in advanced mathematics and its applications to epidemiological modeling.   Furthermore, this collaborative team was composed of mathematicians who are also mothers and understand the challenges and importance of support systems to for professionals who are also parents. We organized a professional development workshop on Mathematicians Navigating Parenthood to help understand how parents can be successful in their careers as mathematicians, and how administrators can help to facilitate their professional goals. Following this, we published an article summarizing strategies to help parents and parents-to-be succeed as well as present proposals on what departments could implement based on their individual policies to provide a welcoming environment to colleagues with, or expecting, children.
